issues.title: Does the API expose which request arguments are optional?
issues.body:
Many API calls have only optional (or some optional) arguments. Some have a simplified nullary signature, such as `describeVpcs` (which might take an associated request object for a more detailed query). Some do not, even though their associated request object has only optional attributes, such as `describeEgressOnlyInternetGateways`. Some request classes specify that an attribute is optional, but they do so informally in the docstring. Either way, `describeEgressOnlyInternetGateways` doesn't.

An application can statically detect that there's a nullary version of a method, making it easy to deduce that it has only optional arguments. As far as I can tell, an application can not statically detect that `describeEgressOnlyInternetGateways` can be called with no arguments (i.e. it has no required arguments). In the case of the latter, a user ostensibly (I mean, I could be missing how) can't determine if its attribute is optional using the Javadoc either.

This information is available in the JSON API descriptions. As far as I can tell from the code gen macros, this isn't exposed in the API via e.g. an annotation. I think it should be: it would make it easier to use the Javadoc to write applications using the SDK manually, and it would also be available for programs to inspect.

Right now, I'm instead finding JAR files and extracting the JSON resource and parsing it. (This is necessary because I don't want to hardcode the version names, which are in the resource's name.) It'd be much more convenient for future users if they didn't have to do that; listing all available resources can be annoying.

issues.title: Error: "The authorization header is malformed"
issues.body:
We have a user report saying that he is getting 

```
The authorization header is malformed; the region 'us-east-1' is wrong; expecting 'eu-west-1'
````

after (I believe) moving from the deprecated `new AmazonS3Client(...)` to the new `AmazonS3ClientBuilder`. 

Previously I raised a question about how to set the region properly in #1423 and based on that we set it to `us-east-1` with the new builder API and I guess that's causing this problem.

In the working version [here](https://github.com/prestodb/presto/blob/c5e1b7c1b636f4d45fcb3e9bd542d13d58de9a43/presto-hive/src/main/java/com/facebook/presto/hive/s3/PrestoS3FileSystem.java#L631-L666) is how we create a new s3 client.

And [here](https://github.com/prestodb/presto/blob/master/presto-hive/src/main/java/com/facebook/presto/hive/s3/PrestoS3FileSystem.java#L624-L675) is the version that throws this error (I suspect L671 is causing the issue).

Note that `pinS3ClientToCurrentRegion` is `false` when the user gets the error. The problem goes away when `pinS3ClientToCurrentRegion` is set to `true`, but the user has buckets in multiple regions so that's not an option.

issues.title: AWS Pricing API missing certain instance types
issues.body:
I'm trying to use Pricing API, but it looks like certain instance types are missing (с5.large for eu-west-3). For example:
```
        Filter parisFilter = new Filter().withType(FilterType.TERM_MATCH).withField("location").withValue("EU (Paris)");
        Filter c5Filter = new Filter().withType(FilterType.TERM_MATCH).withField("instanceType").withValue("c5.large");
        AWSPricing pricing = AWSPricingClientBuilder.standard().withCredentials(creds).withRegion("us-east-1").build();
        pricing.getProducts(
                new GetProductsRequest()
                        .withServiceCode("AmazonEC2")
                        .withFilters(parisFilter, c5Filter)
        )
                .getPriceList()
                .forEach(System.out::println);
```
The code above returns nothing, despite c5.large is actually available for eu-west-3.
c5.18xlarge is also missing.

If I change instance type filter to c5.xlarge, the code will return 4 lines:
```
{"product":{"productFamily":"Compute Instance","attributes":{"enhancedNetworkingSupported":"Yes","memory":"8 GiB","dedicatedEbsThroughput":"Upto 2250 Mbps","vcpu":"4","locationType":"AWS Region","storage":"EBS only","instanceFamily":"Compute optimized","operatingSystem":"Windows","physicalProcessor":"Intel Xeon Platinum 8124M","clockSpeed":"3.0 Ghz","ecu":"16","networkPerformance":"Up to 10 Gigabit","servicename":"Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud","instanceType":"c5.xlarge",....}
....
```

Another inconvenient thing is that I cannot filter by region code (like eu-west-3), only by Human Readable name, which is not available anywhere else.

issues.title: XMLInputFactory Lock Contention
Allow a user to add a JVM shutdown hook to drain metrics queue
issues.body: Metrics published asynchronously are sometimes lost when the JVM shuts down, which can happen relatively often in serverless environments. This usually is not a problem, because there is usually little impact from the loss of a few metrics, but in some cases the user would want to make sure the metrics are fully released before the JVM shutdown finishes. A shutdown hook (or similar mechanism) should be introduced to allow this.

issues.title: Feature Request: Bandwidth Throttling for S3 Transfer Manager
issues.body: The S3 transfer manager should be able to limit (in some way) the bandwidth used when uploading multiple files to prevent saturating the network on a host. This is similar to the feature discussed in this blog post: https://www.instaclustr.com/blog/2016/04/20/cassandra-backups-using-aws-transfermanager/

issues.title: Uploading from a stream from cloudfront fails non-deterministically
issues.body:
We are observing something similar to  https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-java/issues/749 .

We upload a file to S3, wait until it's done. Then we open an URLConnection to this file via CloudFront, and upload it somewhere again, using it's InputStream.

In some cases, this fails with: 

    SdkClientException: More data read than expected: dataLength=457963; expectedLength=454759;

The expected is correct length of the file. I have no idea where the extra data are coming from.

Provided that S3 confirmed the upload was done, and CloudFront is supposed to cache it transparently, what else could be the cause?
What should we do to prevent this from happening?

Downloading locally and uploading will cause a major performance drawback.
Giving it "some time" is not a deterministic solution.

Our Application keeps running into :

 `Unable to execute HTTP request: Timeout waiting for connection from pool

We are suspecting that our pool settings is too low, but it seems to be impossible to create monitoring on the current status of the connection pool.

issues.title: ProgessEvents continue to arrive after TransferManager.shutdownNow()
Is the documentation correct re: md5 vs ETag?
issues.body: If I understand the situation correctly, an object's ETag is equivalent to its md5 checksum if it was uploaded in a single part and less than 5GB in size, but is calculated differently otherwise. However, the [getETag javadoc](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSJavaSDK/latest/javadoc/com/amazonaws/services/s3/model/ObjectMetadata.html#getETag--) says that the ETag *is* the same as the md5 checksum, and the [getContentMD5 doc](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSJavaSDK/latest/javadoc/com/amazonaws/services/s3/model/ObjectMetadata.html#getContentMD5--) says that this will be the same as the ETag. Is this documentation out of date?

issues.title: AmazonEC2Exception Error Code: RequestExpired from AmazonEC2 initialised with StaticCredentialsProvider
issues.body:
We're seeing a lot of this exceptions in our `aws-sdk-java` usage with the following stack trace:
```
com.amazonaws.services.ec2.model.AmazonEC2Exception: Request has expired. (Service: AmazonEC2; Status Code: 400; Error Code: RequestExpired; Request ID: 213aa903-1660-42b7-838f-176cbed53e74)
	at com.amazonaws.http.AmazonHttpClient$RequestExecutor.handleErrorResponse(AmazonHttpClient.java:1639)
	at com.amazonaws.http.AmazonHttpClient$RequestExecutor.executeOneRequest(AmazonHttpClient.java:1304)
	at com.amazonaws.http.AmazonHttpClient$RequestExecutor.executeHelper(AmazonHttpClient.java:1056)
	at com.amazonaws.http.AmazonHttpClient$RequestExecutor.doExecute(AmazonHttpClient.java:743)
	at com.amazonaws.http.AmazonHttpClient$RequestExecutor.executeWithTimer(AmazonHttpClient.java:717)
	at com.amazonaws.http.AmazonHttpClient$RequestExecutor.execute(AmazonHttpClient.java:699)
	at com.amazonaws.http.AmazonHttpClient$RequestExecutor.access$500(AmazonHttpClient.java:667)
	at com.amazonaws.http.AmazonHttpClient$RequestExecutionBuilderImpl.execute(AmazonHttpClient.java:649)
	at com.amazonaws.http.AmazonHttpClient.execute(AmazonHttpClient.java:513)
	at com.amazonaws.services.ec2.AmazonEC2Client.doInvoke(AmazonEC2Client.java:15651)
	at com.amazonaws.services.ec2.AmazonEC2Client.invoke(AmazonEC2Client.java:15627)
	at com.amazonaws.services.ec2.AmazonEC2Client.executeDescribeInstances(AmazonEC2Client.java:7621)
	at com.amazonaws.services.ec2.AmazonEC2Client.describeInstances(AmazonEC2Client.java:7597)
	at com.amazonaws.services.ec2.AmazonEC2Client.describeInstances(AmazonEC2Client.java:7633)
```

We don't use the `aws-sdk-java` directly, but through another tool which creates an instance of `AmazonEC2` with `StaticCredentialsProvider`.

According to the `RequestExpired` [error code description](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/APIReference/errors-overview.html):

> The request reached the service more than 15 minutes after the date stamp on the request or more than 15 minutes after the request expiration date (such as for presigned URLs), or the date stamp on the request is more than 15 minutes in the future. If you're using temporary security credentials, this error can also occur if the credentials have expired.

We're not using temporary security credentials, the `StaticCredentialsProvider` is initialised with an `AWSCredentials` directly (`AWSAccessKeyId` and `AWSSecretKey`).

I don't understand how this could happen. As far as I can tell, the static credentials don't need to be refresh at any point and the computer time settings are configured correctly. 

I can't really share a sample project showing this because it's hard to reproduce, we only have the Java logs. Is there something we could do different to avoid the `RequestExpired` error?

issues.title: Feature Request: Consider a new approach for AmazonS3#getObject
issues.body:
The `S3Object` is unnecessarily tough to work with because it has a close method and it's #getObjectContent result also has a close method. Closing one will close the other since they use the same connection.

While I do appreciate being saved a round trip to S3, it comes at the expense of a simple way to manage resources. Also, of course, you can only call #getObjectContent once which makes retries complex. What might have been nicer is an `S3Object` that is itself an `InputStream`. This would be similar to how `FileInputStream` has a `getFD` method. `S3ObjectInputStream` could have a #getMetaData method. Maybe even a reset that can make a new request. 

I think many first time AWS SDK users don't think of S3Object as an open connection given it's name and it's #getObjectContent method. 

Low priority but I've seen it bite a few people, especially when deciding to pass around an `S3Object` vs an `S3ObjectInputStream`.

issues.title: There should be a region endpoint that allows all regions to be retrieved without an SDK update.
issues.body: We have code that iterates all regions and (for example) calls describe instance on each for a given credential. The SDK should provide region enums as a convenience, not a necessity.  All clients should work with new regions that show up. Partition files should be pulled from an URL instead of json baked into the SDK build. Then `RegionUtils.getRegions()` would return all current regions (or at least as current as the last time that process started). If the regions URL is not available then it could fall back onto the baked-in JSON partition files.

issues.title: TransferManager download does not complete until after SocketTimeoutException is encountered
issues.body:
We are trying to download a large (6GB) file from S3. On our slow connection, this takes about 20 minutes. Initially, we were seeing intermittent SocketTimeoutExceptions, although when we didn't see that issue, things worked fine. We raised the socket timeout to 25 minutes in response.

Now the download seems to hang after actually pulling down all the data. Initially, we were just using the Download.waitForCompletion(), but we wanted more feedback. We added a loop to report the progress, and it showed the percentage as '99.98596920967103' for 12 minutes. Then it encountered "SocketTimeoutException: Read timed out" and indicated that it would retry the download. The completion percentage showed as '100' for about 20 seconds. Then it completed and things worked correctly from there.

issues.title: Datetime ISO8601 not respected by doParseISO8601Date
issues.body:
The current com.amazonaws.util.DateUtils method 'doParseISO8601Date' does not correctly parse ISO 8601 date-time strings without a millisecond field but with a timezone offset

Fails with: 2017-11-13T15:09:59+03:00
Succeeds with: 2017-11-13T15:09:59.0+03:00

It will only cope with date-time strings that have a 'Z' timezone designation without milliseconds 

It has a special case for some spot instance servers?  Where '+0000' is mapped directly to a 'Z' timezone designator

issues.title: Uploads < MultipartUploadThreshold do not publish events to ProgressListener
issues.body:
[Uploads via UploadResult.call()  only conditionally publish events to ProgressListener](https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-java/blob/master/aws-java-sdk-s3/src/main/java/com/amazonaws/services/s3/transfer/internal/UploadCallable.java#L125)

Uploads smaller than MultipartUploadThreshold call uploadInOneChunk() and do not trigger the TRANSFER_STARTED_EVENT and also do not trigger the TRANSFER_FAILED_EVENT [as opposed to the uploadInParts() function](https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-java/blob/master/aws-java-sdk-s3/src/main/java/com/amazonaws/services/s3/transfer/internal/UploadCallable.java#L193) 


 As a result, non-blocking calls to TransferManager.upload , as illustrated [in the example here](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/HLuploadFileJava.html), will hang indefinitely unless  the Upload is explicitly polled via Upload.getState() or the thread is blocked via Upload.waitForCompletion() . This contradicts the documentation, where these calls are marked as optional.

issues.title: Resuming download with TransferManager not working after JVM restart
issues.body:
For demonstration purposes I've made a short program using aws java sdk 1.11.118: https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B5I97wOzbG7MdDBDVkVjZVVWejA/view?usp=sharing

On the first run it starts downloading a +300MB file but exits when it's half done. It uses every chance to save the download state. 

On second run it reads the state file to resume the download. But it always starts from the beginning and takes twice as long as the first run.

Unfortunately it looks like the download state is only saved in the beginning and when the last parts are being downloaded and concatenated.

I've tried adding a shutdown hook to call download.pause() and save that state without success.

I see that com.amazonaws.services.s3.transfer.internal.DownloadPartCallable.java deletes all the parts on JVM exit which was a little surprising since com.amazonaws.services.s3.transfer.internal.CompleteMultipartDownload only joins them in the end. issues.title: MFA support like in other AWS SDKs
issues.body:
Hello,  

We started to use the [switch role feature](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_roles_use_switch-role-console.html) a couple of months ago and we are using the [MultiFactorAuthPresent condition](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_credentials_mfa_example-policies.html), therefore forcing users to be logged in using their MFA and it’s working perfectly.

It’s working in the web console, it’s working with AWS CLI and with many AWS SDKs (like boto3 or the Go SDK) since those SDKs are reading the [mfa_serial](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/topic/config-vars.html#using-aws-iam-roles) field in the `~/.aws/credentials` file.

  I tested the most recent Java SDK for AWS (1.11.213) and it seems like it’s not supported.   Would it be possible to read the mfa_serial field in the .aws/credentials and then ask the MFA when starting a Java process?  

See a related issue in the Go SDK: https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go/issues/842

Thanks!

issues.title: Replace S3 downloadInParallel by using Content-Range requests instead of undocumented S3 part requests
issues.body:
As stated in #1172  AWS SDK for Java currently uses an undocumented S3 functionality to parallelize downloads using part requests instead of using the documented Content-Range requests as AWS SDK for Ruby and Python do.

There are two advantages for changing the current behaviour:

1. Using Content-Range requests is much more flexible as the client can use arbitrary part sizes for downloads instead of the predefined part sizes which were created when the object was uploaded. This can potentially speed up the transfer by using more parts than during upload or a different part size. Also the initial HEAD request to retrieve the number of parts will not be necessary, speeding up the time to start the download and thus reducing time to first byte latency.
2. AWS SDK for Java would use officially documented S3 functionality instead of undocumented functionality which will reduce issues with S3 compatible solutions

issues.title: does ForceGlobalBucketAccess enable the client to upload to a bucket with any acceleration mode?
Add DynamoDBMapperConfig caching
issues.body:
Instead of creating a new builder and a new config object (and doing all the merging) for every operation with a `DynamoDBMapperConfig` parameter, `AbstractDynamoDBMapper` should cache and reuse these configurations. [WeakHashMaps](http://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/WeakHashMap.html) (with optional [SoftReferences](http://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/lang/ref/SoftReference.html)) should do the trick, or use some third party caching solution.
As an intermediate but also more secure solution, you might even extend `DynamoDBMapperConfig` with a (boolean) `shouldCache` field, and cache only these configurations.

Basically you should do the same with all of your **\*Config** classes and wherever you might have the possibility to reuse objects instead of creating functional duplicates (in the whole sdk).
(And of course to benefit from it, your users should use reusable (e.g. static/singleton) config parameters, so you might wanna propagate this in the javadoc too.)

issues.title: DynamoDB exceptions
issues.body:
DynamoDB should have dedicated **exception types** for all errors (listed under [Error handling](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/Programming.Errors.html) and [Common errors](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/amazondynamodb/latest/APIReference/CommonErrors.html)) that should require special handling in the client. (e.g. there is a `LimitExceededException`, `ProvisionedThroughputExceededException`, etc. but there is **no** `ThrottlingException`, `UnrecognizedClientException`, etc.).

See also #826.

issues.title: SimpleDB: ConditionalCheckFailedException
issues.body:
Add dedicated `ConditionalCheckFailedException` to SimpleDB similar to DynamoDB's `com.amazonaws.services.dynamodbv2.model.ConditionalCheckFailedException`.

Right now in SimpleDB this exception can be detected only by comparing the `statusCode` (int) and `errorCode` (string) fields of the very base `AmazonServiceException`; and the possible errorCode values are defined only in the [API documentation](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonSimpleDB/latest/DeveloperGuide/APIError.html).

Basically you should have dedicated exception types for all errors that should require special handling in the client.

See also #826.

Not all s3 requests in sdk provide option for setting Requester pays
issues.body:
Some s3 requests in sdk already support setting requester pays option, for example: 

- DeleteObjectsRequest

- InitiateMultipartUploadRequest

- GetObjectMetadataRequest

- CopyObjectRequest

However there are some requests from which this option is missing:

- GetBucketLocationRequest

- ListObjectsRequest

And we are seeing 403 error for these requests. As a workaround we are setting requester pays option via custom header. Something like:
`request.putCustomRequestHeader("x-amz-request-payer", "requester");`

Performance Bottleneck: TransferManager downloadDirectory
issues.body:
In the `TransferManager.downloadDirectory` a [depth-first-search has been implemented](https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-java/blob/d65733f87550d74a042e30f630c4b9033b6e3372/aws-java-sdk-s3/src/main/java/com/amazonaws/services/s3/transfer/TransferManager.java#L1210) where the list objects request is formed as below:

```
ListObjectsRequest listObjectsRequest = new ListObjectsRequest().withBucketName(bucketName)
                            .withDelimiter(DEFAULT_DELIMITER).withPrefix(prefix);
```
Well when we want to download all of the files of a directory based on a `KeyFilter` then why do we need a `ListObjectsRequest.withDelimiter`. Instead we could just have had:

```
ListObjectsRequest listObjectsRequest = new ListObjectsRequest().withBucketName(bucketName)
                            .withPrefix(prefix);
```

I have more than 13000 files which I can list easily in 14 API calls with the latter method. But the `downloadDirectory()` call makes 27000 API calls for the same because at each API call it goes down just 1 level of virtual directory.

Is there a particular justification for such implementation using `withDelimiter(DEFAULT_DELIMITER)` because as far as I see all possible filtering can be achieved through `KeyFilter` and `keyPrefix`.

Wrapping non-markable streams inside ReleaseableInputStream can lead to ResetException / Resetting to invalid mark
issues.body:
We're getting an issue very much like #427 where a download reset is attempted, which fails. The source of the stream is an upload through dropwizard (which is a DataHead.ReadMultiStream); it is then piped through our encryption code using PipedInputStream/PipedOutputStream, and one of our own streams. At no point do we use a BufferedInputStream, nor do we have any streams that suggest markSupported=true.

It seems that the exception is happening due to the use of SdkFilterInputStream, which ultimately extends from BufferedInputStream, which comes from wrapping it in a ReleaseableInputStream.

```
AmazonS3Client:
            // When input is a FileInputStream, this wrapping enables
            // unlimited mark-and-reset
            if (input != null)
                input = ReleasableInputStream.wrap(input);
```

```
ReleaseableInputStream:
    public static ReleasableInputStream wrap(InputStream is) {
        if (is instanceof ReleasableInputStream)
            return (ReleasableInputStream)is;   // already wrapped
        if (is instanceof FileInputStream)
            return ResettableInputStream.newResettableInputStream((FileInputStream)is);
        return new ReleasableInputStream(is);
    }
```

```
public class ReleasableInputStream extends SdkFilterInputStream implements Releasable {
```

So, I believe this bug is entirely internal to the S3 client.

Information about consumed capacity would be very handy to optimize the load on DB but it's not returned by` load()`, `save()` and `delete()` methods of DynamoDBMapper. Even though underlying AmazonDynamoDBClient provides it, it's simply discarded.
We can change

`public <T> void delete(...)`
into

Any ideas what way to follow? Once decided I can contribute.

issues.title: Executor services use default ThreadFactory, resulting in unhelpful thread names in dumps
issues.body:
When debugging thread leaks and thread-pool leaks, it is very valuable to have thread names which are meaningful and provide some indication as to their origin and purpose.

A variety of classes in the SDK call Executors.new.*executor, which returns a java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor (or subclass) using the DefaultThreadFactory.  The DefaultThreadFactory in turn names threads using the naming scheme pool-{pool number}-thread-{thread number}.

In the event of SDK classes containing these executors getting garbage collected, the executors get orphaned (but are still alive and uncollectable), making it difficult/impossible to detect from a heap dump where the executors came from.

A substantial improvement would be to provide a CustomThreadFactory, which takes as an argument a naming prefix, then using that CustomThreadFactory everywhere an Executor is created (using the static methods that accept a ThreadFactory as the last argument); in this way, from a thread dump of the JVM, it will be possible to tell the origin and purpose of each thread allocated by the SDK.

One very good example of this in action is the org.springframework.scheduling.concurrent.CustomizableThreadFactory in Spring.

This would really help in cases where it might not be immediately obvious to a casual user of the SDK that a class is going to create a thread pool; for example, in the InstanceProfileCredentialsProvider.  In the event of a leak, getting a thread dump would give the user an immediate idea of where to look for the problem.

However - I can't think of a good reason _not_ to move it up to earlier in the piece and it might even be useful from a permissions perspective - if the app doesn't have permissions to write might as well bomb before we've even started trying to download.

Thanks for the PR - good catch. I think in terms of implementation though we're potentially just dodging the problem - as soon as you get MAX_RETRIES >= 63 we're going to have the same issue (ie: Long's overflow) - we might be better adding another call to Math to help us. `Math.max(1, 1 << retriesAttempted)`

Also we should use the same with all the pre-canned back-off strategies.

'eagerlyRefreshing' is the current default behaviour when 'refreshCredentialsAsync' is true - in order to remain backwards compatible this has to be the default behaviour of this constructor: `public InstanceProfileCredentialsProvider(boolean refreshCredentialsAsync)`

I agree that it's `new InstanceProfileCredentialsProvider(true, false)` is probably the most logical default because it's safe in both ec2 and non-ec2 scenarios - however customers may be relying on the previous behaviour.

refresh forces the underlying fetcher to refresh from the metadataservice - by nulling out the credentials it has cached (effectively forcing a fresh grab on the next call to `getCredentials()`. This is the intended behaviour of the `refresh` method on `AWSCredentialsProvider`.
That makes sense to me, I'll update.
Nitpick: Additional spaces here?
Nitpick: more extra white-space

I get that mapper.writeValueAsString is going to convert this to `{"fruit": "pair", "color": "green" }` but since this feature is to convert a string (and avoid having to do the conversion to an object) it might make sense for this test to show-case the _actual_ input string. So when I'm reading the test I can look at the actual JSON string above.
Nitpick: spelling - 'pair' is two of something, 'pear' is the fruit :)
Be cool to see a test for a JSON list too - assume this method should support that also?
Don't bother catching this, converting to a `RuntimeException` and re-throwing, just add the `throws Exception` to the test method signature.
This looks like an unused import.

Can we get a comment here so that we're consistent with the other methods. Something along the lines of
```java
/**
 * Sets the value of the specified key to an object represented by the JSON
 * structure passed.
 */
```

nitpick: it'd also be good to move this method down to just above `public ValueMap with(String key, Object val)` rather than having it in amongst the numeric setters.
There's a few unused imports
Can we add suppress warnings here `@SuppressWarnings("unchecked")` (and for the cast to List below) ?
typically we'd go with full name here so `increment`
All source (including contributions) are licensed under apache 2.0 - we'll have to update the copyright here
Either-way it's the pojo dictating it right? What's the difference between it being in the annotation vs in the property?
Might need a null check for `getMatchingETagConstraints`

Is there a reason you sometimes reference the property directly `!nonmatchingEtagConstraints.equals(that.nonmatchingEtagConstraints)` and you sometimes use the getter `getModifiedSinceConstraint() != null ? !getModifiedSinceConstraint().equals(that.getModifiedSinceConstraint()` ?
Any reason you don't use `instanceof` instead of `getClass()`? It seems like it would cover the null scenario; it's also more consistent with the other equals operators in the SDK.

I think wars have been fought over this topic already so I don't really want to go into the pros/cons of each approach. 😃 Josh Bloch (Effective Java) recommends using `instanceof` ([see here](http://www.artima.com/intv/bloch17.html)) and it's what the rest of the SDK does.

If we make the `equals`/`hashCode` methods final then we somewhat mitigate the issue because we can preserve the `a.equals(b) == b.equals(a)` behaviour even across subclasses.

`instanceof` is consistent with the rest of the SDK so I'd prefer to stick to that for now as it's less surprising.
Thanks - sorry to be a stickler but when faced with these sorts of decisions I usually opt for consistency - it's important that we do our best to ensure the SDK behaves in a predictable way.

issues.title: Use integrated Windows authentication when connecting to AWS via Windows proxy
issues.body:
In order to avoid having to store/maintain a username and password while connecting to AWS via an authenticating Windows proxy (a requirement of many an IT security department I'm sure, but at least here), the AWS SDK could use the features of the Apache HTTP client to do Windows "integrated authentication" / NTLM.

One light-weight way to do this would be to provide the ability for an SDK user to customise the Apache HttpClientBuilder (as created in the SDKs ApacheHttpClientFactory class), by being able to specify a CredentialsProvider and DefaultAuthSchemeRegistry given the otherwise extra optional dependencies Windows authentication would need (httpclient-win, JNA).

Is the SDK use of the Apache HTTP client classes meant to be shielded off from SDK users?

Does this feature (either supporting directly, or via permitted customisation) seem like something that would reasonably fit?

aws-cli role assumption profiles are incompatible with SDK
issues.body:
The [CLI userguide](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/userguide/cli-roles.html) instructs you to add delegated profiles to the file `~/.aws/config`. However, profiles added here are incompatible with the SDK.

JavaDoc in [`com.amazonaws.profile.path.AwsProfileFileLocationProvider`](https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-java/blob/1.11.24/aws-java-sdk-core/src/main/java/com/amazonaws/profile/path/AwsProfileFileLocationProvider.java) makes it clear that only one config file will be loaded (`~/.aws/credentials` or `~/.aws/config`).

The confusion may be that CLI profiles that use keys _are_ defined in `~/.aws/credentials` but profiles that use `source_profile` should be placed in `~/.aws/config`. More details in the CLI [configuration section](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/userguide/cli-chap-getting-started.html#cli-config-files).

The workaround for this problem is to define the role assumption profile in `~/.aws/credentials` without the `profile` prefix. However, there are other tools that do not expected delegated profiles in this file, so this solution is imperfect.

`~/.aws/credentials`

```
[stage]
role_arn = arn:aws:iam:: 123456789012:role/delegated-admin
source_profile = default
```

It would be very helpful if the Java SDK allowed role assumption profiles to be defined using the documented CLI format.

issues.body:
Jackson has a feature whereby with @AnyGetter [1] and @AnySetter annotations a serializable bean can handle JSON properties that aren't accounted for in the modeled properties (while keeping the benefits of the defined model).

Currently, with DynamoDbMapper this is only supported with a fully custom marshaller. However, this means that you've lost the benefit of modeling the known attributes and their constraints. issues.title: Mutipart upload from InputStream (without supplying content-length) uses putObject().
issues.body:
I am calling `com.amazonaws.services.s3.transfer.TransferManager.upload(String, String, InputStream, ObjectMetadata)` and expect it to upload the stream in chunks but the API tried to upload it in one chunk.

After digging in the code a bit what I discovered this is the problematic call order:
`com.amazonaws.services.s3.transfer.internal.UploadCallable.call()` 
`com.amazonaws.services.s3.transfer.internal.UploadCallable.isMultipartUpload()`
`com.amazonaws.services.s3.transfer.internal.TransferManagerUtils.shouldUseMultipartUpload(PutObjectRequest, TransferManagerConfiguration)`
`com.amazonaws.services.s3.transfer.internal.TransferManagerUtils.getContentLength(PutObjectRequest)`

The `getContentLength` returns -1 if the input is a stream (and content-length wasn't supplied).
The `shouldUseMultipartUpload` returns true if `contentLength > configuration.getMultipartUploadThreshold()` and since -1 is not larger than that it doesn't use multi-part upload (and for me later fails because my stream is too big to buffer by the API).

issues.title: Make EC2MetadataClient.readResource() fail fast in when outside of EC2
issues.body:
# Scenario

[readResource()](https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-java/blob/master/aws-java-sdk-core/src/main/java/com/amazonaws/internal/EC2MetadataClient.java#L82) makes use of `HttpURLConnection` to get metadata. When running this code outside of an EC2 instance the connection rightly fails due to the unavailability of http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/instance-id outside of EC2.

The exception raised in this case is a `java.net.SocketException: Connection reset`. As far as I can tell from my testing the time taken to raise this exception is dependent upon the configuration of the outbound 'point-of-egress' network infrastructure. For example I discovered that whilst tethered through my phone I consistently get much quicker connection resets than whilst connected to our corporate infrastructure, which take several minutes to issue the reset packets. Incidentally I did try to configure the `HttpURLConnection` instance whilst in a debugger, setting `connection.setConnectTimeout(5L)` however this seems to have no effect.
# Problem

I'm raising this as an issue because it is frustrating to have to wait for several minutes each time I want to test code locally outside of EC2. My particular use case is that I'm using Spring's [Cloud AWS](http://cloud.spring.io/spring-cloud-aws/) framework and this issue causes the Spring container to pause for several minutes upon startup when running locally. I have investigated whether it's possible only to initialise the `EC2MetadataClient` however this doesn't seem to be the case.

Would it be possible to introduce some sort of "am I in EC2 check" which fails fast prior to trying to obtain the meta-data? This would really ease the development cycle frustrations here.

Hope this makes sense, happy to provide more information if needed.

Many thanks!

review_comments.body: This will be a breaking change as customers who are getting object metadata before will get null now.

We model the request and response classes as per service team (Amazon S3 in this case) specifications. The members in GetObjectRequest are based on the S3 Get Object specification. We cannot add it to the request class if we are not sending it over wire.
No, the s3Object is only populated for serial downloads. For parallel downloads, the s3Object will always be null. That is the reason we store object metadata and return it for parallel downloads.

We use object metadata in 3 different places during Download operation.
1) [Get last modification time](https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-java/blob/master/aws-java-sdk-s3/src/main/java/com/amazonaws/services/s3/transfer/TransferManager.java#L1044).
2) [Get content length](https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-java/blob/master/aws-java-sdk-s3/src/main/java/com/amazonaws/services/s3/transfer/TransferManager.java#L1054)
3) In [DownloadImpl](https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-java/blob/master/aws-java-sdk-s3/src/main/java/com/amazonaws/services/s3/transfer/internal/DownloadImpl.java#L80) task, return metadata when requested by customer. See the other comment.

It is highly unlikely that customers will provide 1 and 2 values. Even then, we need object metadata to use in (3) for parallel downloads. The only solution I see to avoid this call is providing the object metadata as a parameter to download method. This is a rare case as most customers want to download an object from bucket/key values and won't have object metadata. So if we expect them to provide it, they have to make an additional call to get object metadata before calling download method which is not great user experience.

I understand your concerns. I agree that making HEAD request to get metadata for each call might be excessive. I am worried that if we remove object metadata from DownloadImpl, it might be a breaking change. I have to think some more on how to fix it in a clean way. I don't have bandwidth this week to work on this. I will look at this issue next week and get back to you. Thanks.

I don't like the word "operating". How about "for detailed description on how to work with Amazon SQS using Java."

pull_requests.title: Moved the assertion verification out of the setEnabledProtocols method.
pull_requests.body: If there is a bug in prepareSocket that prevents setEnabledProtocols from being called, the covering tests never fail as no assertion is verified. The extreme case is that you can remove the entire code of prepareSocket and no test will complain about it. This pull request contains a small change to improve the tests in order to catch that kind of error.

pull_requests.title: Use 8k buffers when downloading into file
pull_requests.body: Writes <= 8k use a stack-allocated buffer whereas larger writes will malloc() / free() a fresh buffer for each write. Since there doesn't appear to be any particular reason to use a 10k buffer, it makes sense to align with the "preferred" buffer size of the JVM of 8k. See http://hg.openjdk.java.net/jdk8u/jdk8u/jdk/file/601a2304ff4a/src/share/native/java/io/io_util.c#l58

pull_requests.title: Add 'stripKeyPrefix' option to TransferManager's downloadDirectory method
pull_requests.body:
Added an option to strip key prefixes to change downloadDirectory method behaviour without breaking backwards compatibility.

See #1321

pull_requests.title: Updating S3AbortableInputStream#close abort delegation
pull_requests.body:
Updating S3AbortableInputStream#close to delegate to S3ObjectInputStream#abort if there is any data remaining in the stream.
    
This is now consistent with the current documentation, and also ensurers that super.abort() is being triggered (which was being done by S3AbortableInputStream#abort and not S3AbortableInputStream#close). Therefore the abort behaviour via abort and close are now consistent.

pull_requests.title: Invalid javascript header, not complaint with the embedded IANA reference
pull_requests.body:
As described in http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc4329.txt application/x-javascript was temporary but not final and therefore this should be changed, while (new) embedded (tv) browsers do support IANA standards, but could perhaps not-know/skip application/x-javascript support which will mean that Javascript will not be executed.

I do understand that many plugins depend on this reference (like the Jenkins S3 plugin), but this is invalid. Any input about use-cases that could be impacted?

Same issue with `v2` version: https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-java-v2/pull/69 and https://wiki.jenkins.io/display/JENKINS/S3+Plugin is using this file for example.

pull_requests.title: Improve error messages when using proxy server.
pull_requests.body:
If using a proxy server and the AWS exception does not
contain a request ID, then that's a potential sign that the
request was rejected at the proxy server, because the
request ID is assigned at the AWS server side.  This patch
helps users troubleshoot this by including the proxy host in
the exception message.

pull_requests.title: Update ClientConfiguration.java
pull_requests.body: Explicitly specify that the request timeout is for the whole request including all retires and not for a single retry to avoid confusion.

pull_requests.title: Bug fixed when sending null in AttributeUpdate
Correct javadoc for setExpirationTimeRuleId: for internal use only
Clear last used provider when refreshing AWSCredentialsProviderChain
pull_requests.body:
Currently `AWSCredentialsProviderChain`'s cache of the last used credential provider is maintained across `refresh()` invocations in the provider chain.  This means that after you've accessed the credentials once, `refresh()` effectively only refreshes the credential provider that was previously accessed; you can never switch to one earlier in the chain via a refresh.

This PR clears the cached last provider in a refresh.

pull_requests.title: Optimize memory usage when reading response in XmlResponsesSaxParser
pull_requests.body: When responses are read, XmlResponsesSaxParser sanitizes the data. XmlResponsesSaxParser::sanitizeXmlDocument converts it back to String and passes it on to a ByteArrayInputStream. This ends up occupying lots of memory when the responses are bigger. Patch addresses this and helps in reducing the memory usage.

review_comments.body: Thank you for the review @steveloughran and @liuml07 . Addressed the review comments in the latest commit.

pull_requests.title: Pass DynamoDb mapper config when using Table Mapper
pull_requests.body:
This is to fix the following scenario

```java
     new DynamoDBMapper(
            dynamoDB,
            DynamoDBMapperConfig.builder()
                .withTableNameOverride(withTableNameReplacement(tableName))
                .build()
     ).newTableMapper(DomainObject.class);
```

In the scenario above, the TableMapper does not respect the mapper config, e.g. in this case the table name override. When loading the object, it uses the `@DynamoDbTable` annotation to find the table name instead of using the override table value.

Some methods already use `config`, but these PR makes the whole class consistent.

pull_requests.title: Add custom update action by @DynamoDBAttribute's new property
pull_requests.body:
I want to set specify update action each non-key attributes.

Add custom update action by @DynamoDBAttribute saveAction.
This action is performed when DynamoDBMapperConfig's SaveBehabior is CUSTOM.
If saveAction is not define (default NONE), it will perform the same as UPDATE does.

Why are the Eclipse project files needed for a Maven project?  Install the m2e plugin and Eclipse will generate the project from the POM.

The OSGi manifest should be generated as part of the Maven build (for example, using the maven-bundle-plugin) rather than being a static file in the source tree.
Closing as this was added in 1.2.13.

Maven can handle both approaches, i.e. a static OSGi manifest or a generated one. The Eclipse project files provided with this commit will not interfere with that. There are many projects at Eclipse.org that provides both Maven and Eclipse artifacts. This means that while you certainly may use m2e, it's not a requirement. The Eclipse IDE is fully capable of producing the bundle without it.

The problem with generating the OSGi is that you then also impose a requirement for a specific build system. Using the manifest as the pristine source for dependencies (somehting that Maven is capable of today), removes this requirement. The IDE is then sufficient to build the bundle. That means that other build tools that depend on the functionality provided by the IDE can build it too.

review_comments.body:
Understood.  The spirit of using `SC_INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR` explicitly was to trigger an automatic retry in `AmazonHttpClient#shouldRetry`.  Note that we store the real HTTP status code/text in  `AmazonServiceException#setErrorCode`.

I guess it comes down to whether there are cases where an AWS service might return an empty response where you wouldn't want to automatically retry?  Perhaps the better change would be to support user-defined retry logic and/or error handlers?
Done.

FWIW we have a number of instances where we've created custom retry logic further up in the application stack (ie. facades around specific services, particularly EMR).  But this is one of the few times that we've needed to apply it at the HTTP layer.

Hey Jason, it turns out that setting the status code in the error response handler ends up having no effect because it's eventually overwritten in `AmazonHttpClient#handleErrorResponse`, so I've removed it here.

And on another note, after making this change we discovered that the reason our EMR API calls were failing is due to a "505 HTTP Version Not Supported".  Looks like this has been a frequent issue with other services on the forums[1] but thought I'd let you know anyway.

[1] https://forums.aws.amazon.com/thread.jspa?threadID=72406

@tenersen, @uriahcarpenter is saying that SLF4J provides modified versions of the log4j classes that route their messages to SLF4J. So, you exclude the real log4j dependency from the AWS SDK, but then _include_ the fake log4j implementation called log4j-over-slf4j. The AWS SDK is still using log4j classes, but gets bound to the fake ones at runtime, which instead send messages to SLF4J and on to whatever you want like logback. You still get all the log messages.

(PS: the AWS SDK is directly pulling in commons-logging, not log4j of course, as noted above. Really the better thing is to exclude commons-logging, and then use the jcl-over-slf4j dependency to similarly intercept calls to Commons Logging.)

No it doesn't conflict. You want exactly one "slf4j-XXX" dependency, since this controls where SLF4J sends its log messages and that can only be one place.  You want the logback binding.

But you can have many "XXX-over-slf4j" dependencies to grab log messages from different frameworks. Note that you couldn't have commons-logging and jcl-over-slf4j in the same project since they are both defining the org.apache.commons.logging classes.

I don't know what happens if you make a circular dependency -- I assume slf4j forbids for example slf4j-over-jcl and jcl-over-slf4j together!

In particular, I do this successfully with AWS:
- exclude its commons-logging dependency
- include jcl-over-slf4j
- include the slf4j-api of course, and also slf4j-jdk14 to log to the JDK logger in the end
- use slf4j directly in my code for logging

Is something else pulling in log4j then? If you exclude commons-logging from aws-sdk-java, then it must be from something else. Try "mvn dependency:tree" to see just what is including what, and then exclude and 'shim' the other dependencies.

I'm not suggesting you use slf4j-jdk14; it's just the one I am using. You can use whatever binding you want, but you can't use several. But this is beside the main point here

This is _not the same thing_ as the "XXX-over-slf4j" bindings, of which you can have many. You seem to be saying you can't get third-party libs to use slf4j when they're written against something like log4j, but you can. That's exactly what "XXX-over-slf4j" is for.

There may be some knock-on complication here but I'm telling you I certainly use the AWS SDK and have no trace of commons-logging or log4j in my project, and I get the log messages, QED!
Agree this has been a bit annoying...  especially since the aws ruby SDK uses AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID : https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-ruby/blob/master/lib/aws/core/credential_providers.rb

Handling the object graph once you know the top-level type is not a problem.  yes, it's true one could define their activity as something like myActivity(Object[] arg1, Object[] arg2, etc.) but that's up to individual users if they want to structure their code that way.  At least by passing in an array of types to fromData, I have the choice to preserve type information or not.

It's really limiting and requires pretty tight coupling in a distributed system like this for the producer of the output to need to know how the consumer will deserialize the data.

E.g. If I have workers written in Ruby, and a decider in Java, the Ruby workers are are expected to include Java type information for deserialization in their JSON output?

The Flow Framework has the actual type information for the activity method arguments available to it.  It would be really helpful to pass it along.

Seems like, with all the confusion out there, plus needing to maintain backwards compatibility, the best thing to do would be for this to check both the authoritative and conventional environment variables.

We would very much like this patch, as the current implementation of the AWS library toolkit interferes with our logging implementation. 

We use logback with its native SLF4J implementation. However, when attempting to use the AWS library it pulls in the log4j library and it's Logger implementation. This prevents SLF4j from using logback, and switches to log4j, which renders our dynamic and static logging configurations invalid. 

Since we implement dynamic logging configuration with logback, switching to log4j is a non-starter. Especially since log4j is a dead project at this point.

It's fully understood how to use exclusions fro SLF4J to exclude older logging frameworks. We use that feature to exclude log4j from cassandra, i.e.: 

 <dependency>
    <groupId>com.netflix.astyanax</groupId>
    <artifactId>astyanax</artifactId>
    <version>1.0.5</version>
    <optional>false</optional>
    <!-- This section of exclusions removes the log4j import by astyanx, via it's 
             inclusion of cassandra, and then log4j    
     -->
    <exclusions>
      <exclusion> 
          <groupId>org.slf4j</groupId>
          <artifactId>slf4j-log4j12</artifactId>
      </exclusion>
      <exclusion> 
          <groupId>log4j</groupId>
          <artifactId>log4j</artifactId>
        </exclusion>
       </exclusions> 
    </dependency>

However, we do want logging for both AWS and for our own internal application. 

I've tried to add the log4j exclusion to the AWS library with no success. 

Here's the layout: 
    \* Our Logging ->  Logback (SLF4J native) ->  dynamic and static logging configuration
    \* AWS Logging -> Pulls in (Log4j). 
Now it depends on the class loader.  If the class loader pulls the AWS logging first, it initializes with log4j. Once this happens SLF4J uses log4j, which renders our dynamic logging invalid. 

If the AWS library were to use SLF4J, then everyone could be happy, as it supports all the popular frameworks. 

-Todd

Hi tnatarajan,

This is actually an intended behavior, as described in javadoc for save operation:

```
For updates, a null value for an object property will remove it from that item in DynamoDB.
```

So for your case, one possible solution would be to use a trimmed domain class that doesn't model the attributes that are expected to remain unchanged.

Considering that this is rather an inconvenient workaround, yet it is still very important for us to avoid any changes that could break existing customers' code, we are thinking of providing a third option for SaveBehavior (something like UPDATE_IGNORE_NULL_ATTRIBUTES), which would force the save operation to NOT remove null-valued attributes.

By doing it, we could both support the desired "partial" UPDATE and keep our code as backward-compatible. What do you think?

Thanks.
-Shuo

I am afraid I cannot provide any ETA on this.
But I have already added this into our backlog, and will keep you updated on our progress.

We moved these classes into a new namespace (com.amazonaws.event), so that they could be shared by both S3 TransferManager and Glacier ArchiveTransferManager.
Currently, we are working on moving S3 client completely to the new namespace, and this should be done by the next release.

The root cause for this issue is that all ProgressListener callbacks are executed in the main thread. This means that the high-level logic of TransferManager could be stuck in an intermediate state, if the provided ProgressListener#progressChanged calls a blocking method.

For example, in the repro code shown above, waitForUploadResult() is called inside listener callback, at which point the TransferManager has finished the low-level transfer but hasn't updated its monitor status. As a result, waitForUploadResult() is stuck in an infinite loop while waiting for the monitor status update, and this in turn blocks the main thread to ever update such status.

In 1.6.0 version, we have fixed this issue by executing all listener callbacks in a separate thread. Also, as part of this change, we have created a new ProgressListener interface in "com.amzonaws.event" namespace, which is shared by both Amazon S3 and Amazon Glacier clients. The previous s3.model.ProgressListener is now deprecated.

For more information, see the release notes:
http://aws.amazon.com/releasenotes/5783184875850572

How the bundle plugin works:
1) It does a byte code analysis of the code, and figures out what external packages are required. It uses this to generate the correct import-package headers.
2) It uses the explicit export-package declarations in the plugin configuration to generate export-package headers. In the pull request I simply exported ALL packages. This is far from ideal, and only classes and interfaces that should be public should be exported. When exporting all packages users can use implementation classes (without even knowing it).

This all happens during the Maven build.

Require-Bundle should never be used, this forces users to install specific bundles, instead of letting them choose how to make certain packages available. If the AWS library uses a large amount of external libraries, you might consider embedding these libraries as private packages in the AWS bundle. The bundle size will get larger, but the bundle will be easier to use

Flow Framework calls fromData passing it the type information of the top level type that it is trying to deserialize, which in the case of activity inputs is Object[]. The serialization format is expected to contain the necessary information to properly handle the round trip serialization/deserialization of types including generic types and collections. Even if Flow Framework passed in an array of types to fromData, your DataConverter needs to be able to handle the object graph within it, for example you may have a field of type Object[]. 

Which serialization format are you using in your custom DataConverter? The JsonDataConverter included in Flow Framework produces JSON with type information (it uses Jackson JSON Processor under the covers).

You are correct in pointing out that Flow Framework has additional type information about the parameters that it can pass to the DataConverter. I was trying to clarify that this would not completely solve the problem in the general case and your serialization format would need some type hints for things like collections, derived types etc. Type hints don't have to be language specific, for example in XML you could use xsi:type. I think to properly implement a cross-language use case you would also need some mechanism to express types in a language neutral way that you can then map to types in each of the languages -- protocol buffers and XSD come to mind. 

That said, we will consider exposing the declared parameter types to the fromData method to make it easier to implement custom DataConverters.

@wmatveyenko better OSGi support would be great.

maven-bundle-plugin will autogenerate a MANIFEST.MF by identifiying the packages used in the code that are not included in the aws-sdk bundle (eg: jackson, javax.mail, etc) and then including them; also adding an export packages list for other bundles to re-use and generating the OSGi required fields (like a bundle-version from the pom version).

The current artifacts I'm picking up off Maven don't include the MANIFEST.MF, this could be improved by adding this to the pom.xml: 

```
<plugin>
  <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
  <artifactId>maven-jar-plugin</artifactId>
  <version>2.4</version>
  <configuration>
    <archive>
      <manifestFile>META-INF/MANIFEST.MF</manifestFile>
    </archive>
  </configuration>
</plugin>
```

However, I recommend reviewing this solution from @paulbakker instead as if should be easier to maintain in the long run if it works well in testing.

The hard-coded MANIFEST.MF doesn't work so well, Maven Bundle plugin might make use of Import-Package which is arguably (depending on how good your imports are at being OSGified) better than Require-Bundle.

If you use Import-Package, when system testing ensure your OSGi system includes the dependencies:
For example in Karaf 2.3.2 you could do:

```
install -s mvn:commons-codec/commons-codec/1.8/jar
install -s mvn:commons-logging/commons-logging/1.1.3/jar
install -s mvn:org.codehaus.jackson/jackson-core-asl/1.9.13/jar
install -s mvn:org.codehaus.jackson/jackson-mapper-asl/1.9.13/jar
install -s mvn:javax.mail/mail/1.4.7/jar
install -s mvn:org.apache.httpcomponents/httpcore-osgi/4.3/jar
install -s mvn:org.apache.httpcomponents/httpclient-osgi/4.2.5/jar
install -s mvn:com.amazonaws/aws-java-sdk/1.5.6/jar # this won't work until you add and update the MANIFEST.MF
```

This doesn't work with your current MANFIRST.MF, because Jackson seems to have renamed their bundles to "jackson-core-asl" and "jackson-mapper-asl" between 1.6 and 1.9.

You can validate whether the MANIFEST.MF supports OSGi by using 

```
osgi:headers AWS SDK for Java
```

in Karaf and this should list the Export-Packages you expect.

The goal is to be safe (as in, not fail every invocation of `run()` when not on an EC2). `new InstanceProfileCredentialsProvider(true)` or `new InstanceProfileCredentialsProvider(true, true)` does not do that because it will attempt to refresh even if `InstanceProfileCredentialsProvider` isn't the provider being used. Well, if you can't accept changes in GetObjectRequest, the other approach is to modify doDownload in TransferManager and pass this timestamp as a separate parameter instead of part of GetObjectRequest. Will you accept such approach?

Use case might looks like not being very likely, but it's legit use case and even AWS recommends to use external lookup tables for storing file data attributes outside of S3 (such as key, size, timestamp). Based on this and various other use cases, I can't see a reason why metadata needs to be pulled 100% of the time ahead of object itself. Yes, it might be needed _sometimes_, but it's not always needed and there is no way to avoid this extra roundtrip now (which btw was avoidable using earlier versions of AWS SDK, so it should be considered as a regression). Refer (for example to 1.9.25) to https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-java/blob/5907106c12d49596a971f7db7676f578ed0bea9c/aws-java-sdk-s3/src/main/java/com/amazonaws/services/s3/transfer/TransferManager.java#L747 where it was possible to actually use TransferManager without pulling metadata beforehand.

First, object metadata is available as soon as object download process is started as it's delivered as part of HEAD. For the purpose of pause/resume, there is no reason to pull the metadata beforehand as last modification time could be obtained from the object itself when pause action will be triggered because it's part of S3Object which is about to be put on pause (which might not even happened). If download not even started, it's not needed, right?

Content length could be already known to the client as part of listAvailableObjects() or by other measures and should be used instead of another round trip to the S3 (if available).

As for the point 3, it wasn't the case before (https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-java/blob/5907106c12d49596a971f7db7676f578ed0bea9c/aws-java-sdk-s3/src/main/java/com/amazonaws/services/s3/transfer/internal/DownloadImpl.java#L54), so I fail to see why you think it's imperative that metadata is available in advance of S3Object download start (it was never promised). The whole point of introducing this separate instance of object metadata into DownloadImpl is to achieve the retrieval of last modified time for persisting the object (https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-java/blob/master/aws-java-sdk-s3/src/main/java/com/amazonaws/services/s3/transfer/internal/DownloadImpl.java#L193). Does it really necessary? If download wasn't started, persist it as 0, if started - pull from the S3Object metadata.

Yes, probably the current solution offered by me is a bit straightforward and nicer one is required, but let's decide how to fix it. I'm open to suggestions. It doesn't make sense to sequentially pull the metadata for each object just to know information we already know...

I would like to keep it consistent with the ObjectMetadataProvider signature: `public void provideObjectMetadata(final File file, final ObjectMetadata metadata);`[https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-java/blob/master/aws-java-sdk-s3/src/main/java/com/amazonaws/services/s3/transfer/ObjectMetadataProvider.java](url)

@kiiadi the difference is whether the increment value is dynamic.  In the case of the annotation the value is hard coded - each time thru when increment or save (using APPEND_SET) is called the value +N is hardcoded to be a constant value.  When it's part of the POJO its dynamic and dictated via the client.   The intent of this logic is the write operation is always an increment - that a client cannot 'reset' the value thru a PUT operation.

I could see the annotation maintaining the initial value but the POJO maintains the incremental value - on first save we write out the annotation value -- for all future writes we increment using the POJO value.

If it makes this PR easier to merge I'd be happy to use the annotation to drive the behavior as that satisfies my use-case -- when I thought about the general solution the above came to mind.  I'm willing to make this work either way.  Cheers --Matt
